# Sperm

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

For other uses, see [Sperm (disambiguation)](/wiki/Sperm_\(disambiguation\)
"Sperm \(disambiguation\)").

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9f/Complete_diagram_of_a_human_spermatozoa_en.svg/350px-
Complete_diagram_of_a_human_spermatozoa_en.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Complete_diagram_of_a_human_spermatozoa_en.svg)

[](/wiki/File:Complete_diagram_of_a_human_spermatozoa_en.svg "Enlarge")

Diagram of a human sperm cell

**Sperm** is the male reproductive [cell](/wiki/Cell_\(biology\) "Cell
\(biology\)") and is derived from the Greek word (σπέρμα) _sperma_ (meaning
"seed"). In the types of [sexual reproduction](/wiki/Sexual_reproduction
"Sexual reproduction") known as [anisogamy](/wiki/Anisogamy "Anisogamy") and
its subtype [oogamy](/wiki/Oogamy "Oogamy"), there is a marked difference in
the size of the [gametes](/wiki/Gamete "Gamete") with the smaller one being
termed the "male" or sperm cell. A uniflagellar sperm cell that is
[motile](/wiki/Motility "Motility") is referred to as a
**[spermatozoon](/wiki/Spermatozoon "Spermatozoon")** , whereas a non-motile
sperm cell is referred to as a **spermatium**. Sperm cells cannot divide and
have a limited life span, but after fusion with [egg cells](/wiki/Ovum "Ovum")
during fertilization, a new organism begins developing, starting as a
[totipotent](/wiki/Totipotency "Totipotency") [zygote](/wiki/Zygote "Zygote").
The [human](/wiki/Human "Human") sperm cell is [haploid](/wiki/Haploid
"Haploid"), so that its 23 chromosomes can join the 23 chromosomes of the
female egg to form a [diploid](/wiki/Diploid "Diploid") cell. [In
mammals](/wiki/Mammalian_reproduction "Mammalian reproduction"), sperm
develops in the [testicles](/wiki/Testicles "Testicles"), stored in the
[epididymis](/wiki/Epididymis "Epididymis"), and is released from the
[penis](/wiki/Penis "Penis").

## Sperm in animals

Further information: [Spermatozoon](/wiki/Spermatozoon "Spermatozoon")

### Function

The main sperm function is to reach the [ovum](/wiki/Ovum "Ovum") and fuse
with it to deliver two sub-cellular structures: (i) the male
[pronucleus](/wiki/Pronucleus "Pronucleus") that contains the genetic material
and (ii) the [centrioles](/wiki/Centrioles "Centrioles") that are structures
that help organize the [microtubule](/wiki/Microtubule "Microtubule")
[cytoskeleton](/wiki/Cytoskeleton "Cytoskeleton").

### Anatomy

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/Sperm-egg.jpg/200px-
Sperm-egg.jpg)](/wiki/File:Sperm-egg.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Sperm-egg.jpg "Enlarge")

Sperm and egg fusing

The mammalian sperm cell consists of a head, neck, a midpiece and a tail. The
head contains the [nucleus](/wiki/Cell_nucleus "Cell nucleus") with densely
coiled chromatin fibres, surrounded anteriorly by an [acrosome](/wiki/Acrosome
"Acrosome"), which contains enzymes used for penetrating the female egg. The
neck contains the sperm [centriole](/wiki/Centriole "Centriole"). The midpiece
has a central filamentous core with many mitochondria spiralled around it,
used for [ATP](/wiki/Adenosine_triphosphate "Adenosine triphosphate")
production for the journey through the female [cervix](/wiki/Cervix "Cervix"),
[uterus](/wiki/Uterus "Uterus") and [uterine tubes](/wiki/Uterine_tubes
"Uterine tubes"). The tail or "[flagellum](/wiki/Flagellum "Flagellum")"
executes the lashing movements that propel the spermatocyte.[1]

During [fertilization](/wiki/Fertilization "Fertilization"), the sperm
provides three essential parts to the [oocyte](/wiki/Oocyte "Oocyte"): (1) a
signalling or activating factor, which causes the
[metabolically](/wiki/Metabolically "Metabolically") dormant oocyte to
activate; (2) the haploid paternal [genome](/wiki/Genome "Genome"); (3) the
[centriole](/wiki/Centriole "Centriole"), which is responsible for forming the
[centrosome](/wiki/Centrosome "Centrosome") and
[microtubule](/wiki/Microtubule "Microtubule") system.[2]

### Origin

The spermatozoa of [animals](/wiki/Animal "Animal") are produced through
[spermatogenesis](/wiki/Spermatogenesis "Spermatogenesis") inside the male
[gonads](/wiki/Gonad "Gonad") ([testicles](/wiki/Testicle "Testicle")) via
[meiotic](/wiki/Meiosis "Meiosis") division. The initial
[spermatozoon](/wiki/Spermatozoon "Spermatozoon") process takes around 70 days
to complete. The [spermatid](/wiki/Spermatid "Spermatid") stage is where the
sperm develops the familiar tail. The next stage where it becomes fully mature
takes around 60 days when it is called a [spermatozoan](/wiki/Spermatozoan
"Spermatozoan").[3] Sperm cells are carried out of the male body in a fluid
known as [semen](/wiki/Semen "Semen"). Human sperm cells can survive within
the female reproductive tract for more than 5 days post coitus.[4] Semen is
produced in the [seminal vesicles](/wiki/Seminal_vesicles "Seminal vesicles"),
[prostate gland](/wiki/Prostate_gland "Prostate gland") and [urethral
glands](/wiki/Urethral_gland "Urethral gland").

In 2016 scientists at [Nanjing Medical
University](/wiki/Nanjing_Medical_University "Nanjing Medical University")
claimed they had produced cells resembling mouse spermatids artificially from
[stem cells](/wiki/Stem_cells "Stem cells"). They injected these spermatids
into mouse eggs and produced pups.[5]

### Sperm quality

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/Sperm_stained.JPG/200px-
Sperm_stained.JPG)](/wiki/File:Sperm_stained.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Sperm_stained.JPG "Enlarge")

Human sperm stained for semen quality testing.

Main article: [Semen quality](/wiki/Semen_quality "Semen quality")

Sperm [quantity](/wiki/Quantity "Quantity") and quality are the main
parameters in [semen quality](/wiki/Semen_quality "Semen quality"), which is a
measure of the ability of [semen](/wiki/Semen "Semen") to accomplish
[fertilization](/wiki/Fertilization "Fertilization"). Thus, in humans, it is a
measure of [fertility](/wiki/Fertility "Fertility") in a [man](/wiki/Man
"Man"). The genetic quality of sperm, as well as its volume and motility, all
typically decrease with age.[6] (See [paternal age
effect](/wiki/Paternal_age_effect "Paternal age effect").)

DNA damages present in sperm cells in the period after [meiosis](/wiki/Meiosis
"Meiosis") but before fertilization may be repaired in the fertilized egg, but
if not repaired, can have serious deleterious effects on fertility and the
developing embryo. Human sperm cells are particularly vulnerable to free
radical attack and the generation of oxidative DNA damage.[7] (see e.g.
[8-Oxo-2'-deoxyguanosine](/wiki/8-Oxo-2%27-deoxyguanosine
"8-Oxo-2'-deoxyguanosine"))

The postmeiotic phase of mouse spermatogenesis is very sensitive to
environmental genotoxic agents, because as male germ cells form mature sperm
they progressively lose the ability to repair DNA damage.[8] Irradiation of
male mice during late spermatogenesis can induce damage that persists for at
least 7 days in the fertilizing sperm cells, and disruption of maternal DNA
double-strand break repair pathways increases sperm cell-derived chromosomal
aberrations.[9] Treatment of male mice with [melphalan](/wiki/Melphalan
"Melphalan"), a bifunctional alkylating agent frequently employed in
chemotherapy, induces DNA lesions during meiosis that may persist in an
unrepaired state as germ cells progress though DNA repair-competent phases of
spermatogenic development.[10] Such unrepaired DNA damages in sperm cells,
after fertilization, can lead to offspring with various abnormalities.

### Sperm size

Related to sperm quality is sperm size, at least in some animals. For
instance, the sperm of some species of fruit fly
(_[Drosophila](/wiki/Drosophila "Drosophila")_) are up to 5.8 cm long — about
20 times as long as the fly itself. Longer sperm cells are better than their
shorter counterparts at displacing competitors from the female’s seminal
receptacle. The benefit to females is that only healthy males carry ‘good’
genes that can produce long sperm in sufficient quantities to outcompete their
competitors.[11][12]

### Market for human sperm

Further information: [Sperm donation](/wiki/Sperm_donation "Sperm donation")

Some [sperm banks](/wiki/Sperm_bank "Sperm bank") hold up to 170 litres (37
imp gal; 45 US gal) of sperm.[13]

In addition to [ejaculation](/wiki/Ejaculation "Ejaculation"), it is possible
to extract sperm through [TESE](/wiki/Testicular_sperm_extraction "Testicular
sperm extraction").

On the global market, [Denmark](/wiki/Denmark "Denmark") has a well-developed
system of human sperm export. This success mainly comes from the reputation of
Danish sperm donors for being of high [quality](/wiki/Sperm_quality "Sperm
quality")[14] and, in contrast with the law in the other Nordic countries,
gives donors the choice of being either anonymous or non-anonymous to the
receiving couple.[14] Furthermore, Nordic sperm donors tend to be tall and
highly educated[15] and have altruistic motives for their donations,[15]
partly due to the relatively low monetary compensation in Nordic countries.
More than 50 countries worldwide are importers of Danish sperm, including
[Paraguay](/wiki/Paraguay "Paraguay"), [Canada](/wiki/Canada "Canada"),
[Kenya](/wiki/Kenya "Kenya"), and [Hong Kong](/wiki/Hong_Kong "Hong
Kong").[14] However, the [Food and Drug
Administration](/wiki/Food_and_Drug_Administration "Food and Drug
Administration") (FDA) of the US has banned import of any sperm, motivated by
a risk of transmission of [Creutzfeldt–Jakob
disease](/wiki/Creutzfeldt%E2%80%93Jakob_disease "Creutzfeldt–Jakob disease"),
although such a risk is insignificant, since artificial insemination is very
different from [the route of transmission of Creutzfeldt–Jakob
disease](/wiki/Creutzfeldt%E2%80%93Jakob_disease#Transmission
"Creutzfeldt–Jakob disease").[16] The prevalence of Creutzfeldt–Jakob disease
for donors is at most one in a million, and if the donor was a carrier, the
infectious proteins would still have to cross the [blood-testis
barrier](/wiki/Blood-testis_barrier "Blood-testis barrier") to make
transmission possible.[16]

### History

See also: [Homunculus § Homunculus of
spermists](/wiki/Homunculus#Homunculus_of_spermists "Homunculus")

Sperm were first observed in 1677 by [Antonie van
Leeuwenhoek](/wiki/Antonie_van_Leeuwenhoek "Antonie van Leeuwenhoek")[17]
using a [microscope](/wiki/Microscope "Microscope"), he described them as
being [animalcules](/wiki/Animalcule "Animalcule") (little animals), probably
due to his belief in [preformationism](/wiki/Preformationism
"Preformationism"), which thought that each sperm contained a fully formed but
small human.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

### Forensic analysis

Ejaculated fluids are detected by [ultraviolet light](/wiki/Uv_light "Uv
light"), irrespective of the structure or colour of the surface.[18] Sperm
heads, e.g. from vaginal swabs, are still detected by
[microscopy](/wiki/Microscopy "Microscopy") using the "Christmas Tree Stain"
method, i.e., Kernechtrot-Picroindigocarmine (KPIC) staining.[19][20]

## Sperm in plants

Sperm cells in algal and many plant [gametophytes](/wiki/Gametophyte
"Gametophyte") are produced in male [gametangia](/wiki/Gametangium
"Gametangium") ([antheridia](/wiki/Antheridium "Antheridium")) via
[mitotic](/wiki/Mitosis "Mitosis") division. In [flowering
plants](/wiki/Flowering_plant "Flowering plant"), sperm nuclei are produced
inside [pollen](/wiki/Pollen "Pollen").[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

## Motile sperm cells

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e9/Plant_sperm.png/220px-
Plant_sperm.png)](/wiki/File:Plant_sperm.png)

[](/wiki/File:Plant_sperm.png "Enlarge")

Motile sperm cells of algae and seedless plants.[21]

Motile sperm cells typically move via [flagella](/wiki/Flagellum "Flagellum")
and require a water medium in order to swim toward the egg for fertilization.
In animals most of the energy for sperm motility is derived from the
metabolism of [fructose](/wiki/Fructose "Fructose") carried in the [seminal
fluid](/wiki/Semen "Semen"). This takes place in the
[mitochondria](/wiki/Mitochondria "Mitochondria") located in the sperm's
midpiece (at the base of the sperm head). These cells cannot swim backwards
due to the nature of their propulsion. The uniflagellated sperm cells (with
one flagellum) of [animals](/wiki/Animal "Animal") are referred to as
**[spermatozoa](/wiki/Spermatozoon "Spermatozoon")** , and are known to vary
in size.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

Motile sperm are also produced by many [protists](/wiki/Protist "Protist") and
the [gametophytes](/wiki/Gametophyte "Gametophyte") of
[bryophytes](/wiki/Bryophyte "Bryophyte"), [ferns](/wiki/Fern "Fern") and some
[gymnosperms](/wiki/Gymnosperm "Gymnosperm") such as [cycads](/wiki/Cycad
"Cycad") and [ginkgo](/wiki/Ginkgo "Ginkgo"). The sperm cells are the only
flagellated cells in the life cycle of these plants. In many ferns and
[lycophytes](/wiki/Lycophyte "Lycophyte"), they are multi-flagellated
(carrying more than one flagellum).[21]

In [nematodes](/wiki/Nematode "Nematode"), the sperm cells are
[amoeboid](/wiki/Amoeboid_movement "Amoeboid movement") and crawl, rather than
swim, towards the egg cell.[22]

## Non-motile sperm cells

Non-motile sperm cells called **spermatia** lack flagella and therefore cannot
swim. Spermatia are produced in a [spermatangium](/wiki/Gametangium
"Gametangium").[21]

Because spermatia cannot swim, they depend on their environment to carry them
to the egg cell. Some [red algae](/wiki/Red_alga "Red alga"), such as
_[Polysiphonia](/wiki/Polysiphonia "Polysiphonia")_ , produce non-motile
spermatia that are spread by water currents after their release.[21] The
spermatia of [rust fungi](/wiki/Rust_\(fungus\) "Rust \(fungus\)") are covered
with a sticky substance. They are produced in flask-shaped structures
containing [nectar](/wiki/Nectar "Nectar"), which attract [flies](/wiki/Fly
"Fly") that transfer the spermatia to nearby [hyphae](/wiki/Hyphae "Hyphae")
for fertilization in a mechanism similar to [insect
pollination](/wiki/Insect_pollination "Insect pollination") in [flowering
plants](/wiki/Flowering_plant "Flowering plant").[23]

Fungal spermatia (also called pycniospores, especially in the Uredinales) may
be confused with [conidia](/wiki/Conidium "Conidium"). Conidia are
[spores](/wiki/Spore "Spore") that germinate independently of fertilization,
whereas spermatia are [gametes](/wiki/Gamete "Gamete") that are required for
fertilization. In some fungi, such as _[Neurospora
crassa](/wiki/Neurospora_crassa "Neurospora crassa")_ , spermatia are
identical to microconidia as they can perform both functions of fertilization
as well as giving rise to new organisms without fertilization.[24]

## Sperm nuclei

In almost all [embryophytes](/wiki/Embryophyte "Embryophyte"), including most
gymnosperms and all [angiosperms](/wiki/Angiosperm "Angiosperm"), the male
[gametophytes](/wiki/Gametophyte "Gametophyte") ([pollen grains](/wiki/Pollen
"Pollen")) are the primary mode of [dispersal](/wiki/Biological_dispersal
"Biological dispersal"), for example via wind or insect
[pollination](/wiki/Pollination "Pollination"), eliminating the need for water
to bridge the gap between male and female. Each pollen grain contains a
spermatogenous (generative) cell. Once the pollen lands on the
[stigma](/wiki/Stigma_\(flower\) "Stigma \(flower\)") of a receptive flower,
it germinates and starts growing a [pollen tube](/wiki/Pollen_tube "Pollen
tube") through the [carpel](/wiki/Carpel "Carpel"). Before the tube reaches
the [ovule](/wiki/Ovule "Ovule"), the nucleus of the generative cell in the
pollen grain divides and gives rise to two sperm nuclei, which are then
discharged through the tube into the [ovule](/wiki/Ovule "Ovule") for
fertilization.[21]

In some [protists](/wiki/Protist "Protist"), fertilization also involves sperm
[nuclei](/wiki/Cell_nucleus "Cell nucleus"), rather than cells, migrating
toward the egg cell through a fertilization tube. [Oomycetes](/wiki/Oomycete
"Oomycete") form sperm nuclei in a [syncytical](/wiki/Syncytium "Syncytium")
[antheridium](/wiki/Antheridium "Antheridium") surrounding the egg cells. The
sperm nuclei reach the eggs through fertilization tubes, similar to the pollen
tube mechanism in plants.[21]

## Sperm centrioles

Most sperm cells have [centrioles](/wiki/Centrioles "Centrioles") in the sperm
neck.[25] Sperm of many animals has 2 centrioles known as the proximal
centriole and distal centriole. Some animals like human have a single
centriole known as the proximal centriole. Mice and rat have no sperm
centrioles. The fruit fly [Drosophila
melanogaster](/wiki/Drosophila_melanogaster "Drosophila melanogaster") has a
single centriole and an atypical centriole named the [Proximal Centriole-
Like](/wiki/Proximal_Centriole-Like "Proximal Centriole-Like") (PCL).[26]

## Sperm tail formation

The sperm tail is a specialized type of [cilium](/wiki/Cilium "Cilium") (aka
flagella). In many animals the sperm tail is formed in a unique way, which is
named [Cytosolic ciliogenesis](/wiki/Cytosolic_ciliogenesis "Cytosolic
ciliogenesis"), since all or part of [axoneme](/wiki/Axoneme "Axoneme") of the
sperm tail is formed in the [cytoplasm](/wiki/Cytoplasm "Cytoplasm") or get
exposed to the cytoplasm.[27]
